46.heading: New York City Police.
46.title: The Green Woman
46.author: written by Peter Straub & Michael Easton ; art by John Bolton ; lettered by Todd Klein.
notes: (Vertigo)

Summary (from SkyRiver): New York City police detective Bob Steele is determined to stop the killing spree of a man who calls himself, among other things, Fielding "Fee" Bandolier, a Vietnam veteran whose many victims' voices talk to both men. At the same time, the evil within an abandoned pub in the Midwest, The Green Woman, calls both men to meet their fates within its walls.
"Suggested for mature readers"

47.title: "New York City 2002"
47.author: by Rob Hingley, Kenny Sylvester, Pete Ciccone, and Pepe Moreno ; illustrated by Pepe Moreno
47.appears_in: p. 58-65 in Heavy Metal, v. 9, no. 13 (i.e., v. 9, no. 1) (Apr. 1985).
notes: Begins: "Welcome to Brooklyn, garden spot of New York, or what used to be New York. It's a mess. Nobody lives here now, at least nobody you'd want to meet. Outcasts and misfits...Rebels. The streets are a battleground. Take a step off your own turf, and you're in big trouble. And then, there's the Sanitation Police."

110.title: The New York Four
110.author: written by Brian Wood ; illustrated by Ryan Kelly ; lettering by Jared K
notes: (Minx)
"Just starting her freshman year at NYU, Riley is about to find out what an adventure
and a mystery

living in New York City can be. The ultimate insider's guide to NYC is seen through the eyes of Brooklyn-born Riley. Raised by stuffy, literati parents, Riley's a shy, straight-A student who convinces three other NYU brainiacs to join a research group for fast cash"

273.title: New York/Miami
notes: New York/Miami / stories by Philippe Paringaux ; illustrated by Jacques de Loustal ; translated from the French original by Elizabeth Bell. -- New York : Catalan Communications, 1990. -- 64 p. : col. ill. ; 32 cm. -- A collection of stories. -- First appeared in Pilote-Mensuel in 1980. -- Call no.: PN6747.L6N413 1990

"New York Miami" p. 3-6 -- Summary: In a story told in large side-captioned panels, a narrator in New York, then Miami, describes moments. He has a small packet of something in his pocket at a moment on the Brooklyn elevated, and it is taken from his coat in a hotel in Miami Beach. A man on Rockaway Beach has strange eyes, and he sees the eyes again in Key Biscayne. The implication is that the narrator is a courier for some illegal substance, but perhaps not a successful one.

"Blues" p. 8-11 -- Summary: Large panels with rhyming captions tell about a hard life in the ghetto, and a whitey killed in an alley. The scene changes, and we see that a blond man has been singing it to a bald man by a pool, and they agree it will go gold or platinum.

"Cruisin' in a Buick" p. 13-16 -- Summary: Remy picks up Denise from the beach in his pink Buick. After awhile she asks to drive, and hits a dog. Denise becomes aroused and they climb into the back seat. The next day they go for a drive as well, but nothing happens. Third day she hits a couple of dachshunds, and is again interested in sex. And so on, until Remy says he's going back to Paris tomorrow, and there aren't many dogs left anyhow. On their last drive, Denise hits an old couple walking their poodle, then takes the Buick off a cliff at 120 mph.

"Miss Fan USA" p. 18-23 -- Summary: A girl in New York dreams of being a groupie, and even contrives to get a backstage pass, but is ignored by the celebrities. She goes back home to her teddy bear, in tears.

"La Vie en Blues" p. 25-27 -- Summary: Six large panels with rhymed captions. Scenes show African Americans on railroad tracks, streets, in bars, and in prison.

"The Great White Hunter" p. 29-35 -- Summary: A European hunter in tropical Africa drinks and finally gets up the courage to shoot himself, and the animals are safe. Half-page panels with captions.

"The Question" p. 37-40 -- Summary: A chauffeur in Miami goes to bed with a woman. Story without words until the final panel, in which she asks, "Is it me or is it my money?"

"Marcello" p. 42-45 -- Summary: A man in a hat accompanies Marcello to an office where they kill another man. The man in the hat is upset that Marcello forgets to kiss him afterwards. The man in the hat wants Marcello to come up for a drink, but Marcello drops him off at the corner.

"Apricot Juice, a 6.35 and a Stuck Horn" p. 47-50 -- Summary: A man in a bar orders apricot juice, finds a gun in the restroom as planned, kills two pool players and runs outside to jump into a waiting DeSoto. Another man reaches into the car and shoots the first man, who falls forward onto the horn. Large panels with side captions.

"Keep Cool, Johnny" p. 52-53 -- Summary: Johnny can't take life in the city, and is afraid to come out of his room. He screws up his courage and moves to a boring town in the Midwest. Happy ending. Six side-captioned panels.

"Manolete, One More Time" p. 55-64 -- Summary: Luis sneaks back into Franco's Spain to remember his dead comrades. He visits his old sweetheart, who chose Diego instead of him. He sees fear in her eyes. Luis goes to a bullfight, and afterward sees an old acquaintance, the one who had Diego shot. Luis is followed, and killed.

This summary is from European Comics in English Translation (Jefferson, NC : McFarland & Company, 2002). Used with permission.
